question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the remainder when $3 \times 13 \times 23 \times 33 \times \ldots \times 183 \times 193$ is divided by $5$.
inference:
Since every odd number greater than $5$ can be expressed as $5m \pm 1$ or $5m \pm 2$, the product
$$3 \times 13 \times 23 \times 33 \times \ldots \times 183 \times 193$$
can be expressed as:
$$3 \times (5 \times 2 \pm 1) \times (5 \times 4 \pm 1) \times (5 \times 6 \pm 1) \times \ldots \times (5 \times 36 \pm 1) \times (5 \times 38 \pm 1)$$
$$=3 \times [(5 \times 2 \times 5 \times 4 \times 5 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 5 \times 36) \pm (5 \times 2 \times 5 \times 4 \times 5 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 5 \times 36)]$$
$$=3 \times [(5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36) \pm (5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36)]$$
$$=3 \times (5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36) \pm 3 \times (5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36)$$
$$=3 \times (5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36) [1 \pm 1]$$
$$=3 \times (5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36) \times 0$$
$$=0$$
Final Answer: \boxed{$0$}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
First, we use the property $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$ implies $ac \equiv bc \pmod{m}$.

Since all numbers with units digit $3$ have a remainder of $3$ when divided by $5$ and there are $20$ numbers,  $$3 \times 13 \times 23 \times 33 \times \ldots \times 183 \times 193 \equiv 3^{20} \pmod{5}.$$Next, we also use the property $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$ implies $a^c \equiv b^c \pmod{m}$.

Since $3^4 \equiv 81 \equiv 1 \pmod5$, and $3^{20} = (3^4)^5$, then $3^{20} \equiv 1^5 \equiv \boxed{1} \pmod{5}$.

question:
Since every odd number greater than $5$ can be expressed as $5m \pm 1$ or $5m \pm 2$, the product
$$3 \times 13 \times 23 \times 33 \times \ldots \times 183 \times 193$$
can be expressed as:
$$3 \times (5 \times 2 \pm 1) \times (5 \times 4 \pm 1) \times (5 \times 6 \pm 1) \times \ldots \times (5 \times 36 \pm 1) \times (5 \times 38 \pm 1)$$

$$=3 \times [(5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36) \pm (5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36)]$$

$$=3 \times (5^9 \times 2 \times 4 \times 6 \times \ldots \times 36) \times 0$$
$$=0$$

ground_truth:
First, we use the property $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$ implies $ac \equiv bc \pmod{m}$.

Since all numbers with units digit $3$ have a remainder of $3$ when divided by $5$ and there are $20$ numbers,  $$3 \times 13 \times 23 \times 33 \times \ldots \times 183 \times 193 \equiv 3^{20} \pmod{5}.$$Next, we also use the property $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$ implies $a^c \equiv b^c \pmod{m}$.

Since $3^4 \equiv 81 \equiv 1 \pmod5$, and $3^{20} = (3^4)^5$, then $3^{20} \equiv 1^5 \equiv \boxed{1} \pmod{5}$.
